required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Canine-Assisted ANxiety Reduction IN Emergency Care IV
clinical_study.official_title: Canine-Assisted ANxiety Reduction IN Emergency Care IV (CANINE IV)

brief_summary.textblock:
Prior literature demonstrates that human stress can be reduced with exposure to animals. This study challenges current dogma by introducing a widely available, low cost method of dog therapy to reduce patient and provider stress. The objectives of this study are to determine if interaction with a certified therapy dog and handler can;
- decrease reported anxiety levels in emergency department (ED) patients,
- decrease salivary cortisol in ED patients,
- decrease total morphine equivalent dosing in the emergency department or at discharge and/or,
- decrease reported stress levels in emergency department providers caring for participating patients
when compared to usual care.

primary_outcome.measure: Morphine equivalent narcotic administration in emergency department patients with chronic pain
primary_outcome.time_frame: Date of enrollment until emergency department discharge, up to 72 hours
primary_outcome.description: Total morphine equivalent narcotic administration while in the emergency department or as a discharge prescription will be recorded for enrolled patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in reported stress levels in ED patients with chronic pain using Wong-Baker FACES Scale (10 = worst)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and T1 (~45 minutes after baseline)
primary_outcome.description: Change in self reported stress levels of emergency department patients using a Wong-Baker FACES Scale for anxiety between baseline and T1

primary_outcome.measure: Change in salivary cortisol in ED patients with chronic pain
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and T1 (~45 minutes after baseline)
primary_outcome.description: Change in salivary cortisol levels in emergency department patients between baseline and T1

primary_outcome.measure: Number of narcotic, sedative and/or neuroleptic doses administered in ED patients with emotional crisis
primary_outcome.time_frame: Date of enrollment until emergency department discharge, up to 72 hours
primary_outcome.description: Number of narcotic, sedative and/or neuroleptic doses administered in ED patients with emotional crisis

primary_outcome.measure: Change in reported stress levels in ED patients with emotional crisis using Wong-Baker FACES Scale (10 = worst)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and T1 (~45 minutes after baseline)
primary_outcome.description: Change in self reported stress levels of emergency department patients using a Wong-Baker FACES Scale for anxiety between baseline and T1

primary_outcome.measure: Change in salivary cortisol in ED patients with emotional crisis
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and T1 (~45 minutes after baseline)
primary_outcome.description: Change in salivary cortisol levels in emergency department patients between baseline and T1

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in salivary cortisol levels in emergency department patients
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and T1 (~45 minutes after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Change in salivary cortisol levels in emergency department patients between baseline and T1

arm_group.description: Emergency department patients enrolled in the control arm will receive usual care. Emergency department providers enrolled in the control arm will work their shift as usual.
Emergency department patients and providers in the intervention arm will be exposed to and/or interact with a certified therapy dog and handler

intervention.description: Exposure to certified therapy dogs and their handler.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Patients
- Age 18-89 years
- Chronic pain, defined as pain on most days for >6 weeks
- Triage pain score >6 out of 10
OR
- Age 18-89 years
- Currently experience crisis, including suicidality, or
- Meet the standard of a provider assessment of "severe stress" defined by their identification that the patient meets a score of greater than six on the FACES stress scale
Providers
• Faculty, residents, advanced practitioners, and nurses who work in the ED and identify themselves as being the nurse or physician of record for the enrolled patients.
Therapy Dog Handlers
• Handler of a certified therapy dog and volunteer of Eskenazi's Therapy Dog Program
Exclusion Criteria:
Patients
- Violent behavior
- Overt intoxication
- Non-English speaking
- Any reported prior fear or adverse reaction to dogs
Providers
• Any reported prior fear or adverse reaction to dogs
Therapy Dog Handlers
• None
